    Question again proposed.

    Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to speak. I was not in the House when the Minister questioned my message on foreign talent. In fact, I was surprised that the Minister chose to misinterpret my call for the toning down of the foreign talent message, as a call against foreign talent. I think this is not fair.

    I have always subscribed to the open system of recruiting the best into our service. And where there are gaps in our recruitment exercise, we should allow foreign talent to come and fill those gaps. But I said that in this crisis, charity begins at home. Did I ask that we should stop them from coming? No. Did I ask that we sack them and replace the vacancies with Singaporeans? No. All that I asked is for the Government to play down this message in this crisis. Is that wrong?

Column: 583



    Is it wrong, Sir, for me to ask that Singaporeans should take priority in the Government's plans to tackle the economic crisis? Is it wrong?

    The Chairman: Dr Tan, I have allowed you to make a brief clarification. Could you round up quickly?

    Dr Tan Cheng Bock: Yes. The Minister is worried that I may send the wrong message to foreigners. I think we should be worried that we might be sending the wrong message to Singaporeans. I was only sending a message of assurance to Singaporeans.

    The Chairman: Dr Tan, you have made the point. I think you are embarking on a new speech. Please resume your seat. The point has been made.

    Dr Tan Cheng Bock resumed his seat.

    The Chairman: General George Yeo, you may continue with your speech.

    The Second Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Thank you, Sir. Yesterday, a number of MPs spoke about the importance of the knowledge economy to Singapore in the next century. This is a crucial area and we should be clear about what we are referring to. We are not talking about particular industries or particular companies. The knowledge economy is not an add-on. What we are talking about is a total national orientation towards brain work, as opposed to manual labour.

    You take the example of Internet and e-commerce. A few nights ago, the US Ambassador in Singapore invited me to dinner to meet Raymond Lane, the President and Chief Operating Officer of Oracle. Oracle is a software company whose capitalisation has now overtaken General Motors, the world's biggest auto company. Raymond Lane said that in the next five years, e-commerce will cause a major change in global manufacturing, distribution and consumption. He thinks that the changes in the next five years

Column: 584

will be as great as the changes that have taken place in the last 60 years. I do not know whether he is right or he is wrong, but even if he is out by five years, I think the point is very clear. Unless we gear ourselves for that new world, we will be left behind.

    At the same dinner, the US Ambassador cited some statistics which I thought were very interesting. America On-Line has also surpassed General Motors in capitalisation. Amazon.com already has a capitalisation greater than that of Boeing Aircraft. One produces 777s and the most advanced aeroplanes in the world and the other sells books, which he does not own. Microsoft, a giant, has a capitalisation greater than that of all the stock markets of the South East Asian countries combined. And little Yahoo has a capitalisation greater than that of the Jakarta stock exchange.

    I do not know whether some of these valuations are exaggerated or whether they reflect underlying realities, but these are facts. And we have got to ask ourselves what is happening in the world. Why is it, when we study Fortune 500 companies, there is such a drastic shift, away from those who dig things from the ground, who bend metals, who do repetitive work, to those which produce creative outputs from the human brain.

    If you look at the balance sheets of AOL or Microsoft, we are hard put to figure out what their assets are, because it is no longer machines, factories or land. It is human knowledge, human network, the culture of a company. When you acquire such a company, you ascribe the difference to goodwill. So even general accounting principles have not quite caught up with the knowledge economy.

    It is therefore crucial that despite the Asian crisis, we keep our eyes on what is coming on the horizon. Internet and e-commerce will shake every industry to its foundations, and it affects all sectors. Dr Wang Kai Yuen was absolutely right. It is not just computers and IT. He talked about Viagra, and asked rather mischievously whether it is part of the knowledge

Column: 585

economy. Well, Viagra is a very interesting drug. It works the same way that nitroglycerine works when you put it under the tongue for heart patients. Recently, Nobel prizes were awarded to the scientists who discovered the biochemistry of these drugs. These are extremely knowledge-intensive industries, which we should become a part of. What Zantac, which is an anti-ulcer drug, has done for Glaxo, Viagra will do for Pfizer.

    The terms of trade have changed. If we are just drawers of water and hewers of wood, machines will take over our work and we will draw only a pittance. The key is working with the human brain, which means educating the young, teaching them to network, not just within Singapore but in the whole world, understanding where the value added is the greatest, and then getting the maximum return from the effort that we put in.

    Of course, not everyone can be a high-tech hot shot, but we must have a significant high-tech sector in Singapore to pull us along. And a knowledge economy applies as much to mundane things like clothing and food. When I go jogging, I wear Chinese singlets which cost me $3. If you buy Calvin Klein, it may cost you 10-20 times the amount, but it is real value Calvin Klein has added, which the Chinese have not quite understood. Singapore's Bodyknits understands this with their range of products and they are now trying to break into the American market. Our poh piah king has recently launched frozen roti prata, and I am told by Singaporeans in Germany that if you put them in a toaster, they come out as good as Jalan Kayu roti prata. Maybe Germany is cold and it is far away, but that really caught my attention. This is part of the knowledge economy, how you turn an existing product and add value to it, enlarge your market and make profits from it, creating jobs and employment for Singaporeans. The key for us is a new kind of entrepreneurship in Singapore.

    Yesterday, Mr Rai talked about the Marwaris in India. The Marwaris are a small tribe from Rajasthan who are incredibly entrepreneurial. If you look at

Column: 586

the Indian stock market, they own many of the companies there. In Calcutta, the Bengalis are great poets, writers, musicians, but the industrialists are almost all Marwaris.

    Entrepreneurship is in the culture of a people. I do not believe that you can easily teach it. I think you either have it as a culture or you do not have it as a culture. And I believe that we have it as a people, because without entrepreneurship in Singapore, the entrepreneurship of our forefathers, the entrepreneurship in the public and private sectors in Singapore, there would not be the Singapore of today. What we need to do is to learn a new kind of entrepreneurship, which is an entrepreneurship which is not evident on the balance sheet, not things you can see and touch, not real estate - and our people are big real estate entrepreneurs - not just in Singapore, but all over South East Asia, Australia, even in Europe and America - but in high-tech, where we are dealing with intangibles, and that requires a new set of skills, a new set of rules and regulations, maybe new laws, new kinds of financing. And this is precisely what the Technopreneurship Committee, chaired by Dr Tony Tan, is trying to do. We have entrepreneurship, but we must migrate it progressively so that our younger people will be able to deal and have skills and knowledge in different industries and products.

    We talk about venture capital. The issue is not money. That are lots of money in Singapore. Venture money is not stupid money, which you throw at things or projects. Venture money is some of the smartest money around. They are making bets on individuals, on companies, on market trends. To build up a venture capital financial market in Singapore will take us many years. We are getting consultants to help us. We have many advisers from Silicon Valley and from elsewhere, but this is a new area for us. Our banks have got to get used to it, credit officers have got to get used to it. Eventually, we will get there.

    We must show to high-tech players in the world that we are fully committed to

Column: 587

this area and we also intend to be a player in this area. We will do everything which is necessary, building up the science park, incubator units, one-stop centres, the whole list which many MPs have talked about and which we will seriously consider. But in the end, what we need is a solid national commitment involving both the public and private sectors, the school system, the universities, a keen determination, a strong will power, to get there, to transfer our value added increasingly from repetitive work to brain work, whether this be in the life sciences, in computers, in fashion, in food, in trade, in logistics, in whatever. It is not something which is abstract for Singaporeans. It is something which all of us can do in our own little circle. And if we can achieve that, change the culture of Singapore, then we will succeed. We have no choice.

    As Mr Inderjit Singh said yesterday, he thought of migrating to America, and many of his friends have done so, because they have this glint in their eyes that there is a prospect of becoming wealthy in a short period of time, and they have left. If we do not have this sector in Singapore and develop technopreneurship in Singapore, and show commitment to it in the way we adjust our rules and regulations, my fear is our own best and brightest will leave, not to talk about the foreigners that we would not be able to attract into Singapore, and our most enterprising and creative may find greener pastures elsewhere.

    As time is short, I think I should end here and give the rest of the time to my colleague, Mr Tang Guan Seng.
12.45 pm

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Tang Guan Seng): Sir, I will reply to some of the points raised by MPs yesterday. Mr Inderjit Singh and Dr Toh See Kiat made some comments on our attractions on Sentosa. Dr Toh said that the Merlion Tower is fiction. But I think there is nothing wrong in it. The Merlion symbol was

Column: 588

created more than 30 years ago by the Tourism Promotion Board. It has become a globally recognised tourist icon for Singapore. When tourists come to Singapore, they like to take photographs with the Merlion. Because of this, Sentosa Development Corporation (SDC) built the Merlion Tower. Since its completion in 1996, about half a million tourists visited this Merlion every year. We must thank the Merlion which has contributed to the tourism industry.

    Sentosa is our top attraction. Despite the economic downturn and the drop in tourist arrivals, last year it attracted 3.3 million tourists. So credit must go to SDC. There are many attractions on Sentosa. Some are privately owned and some are owned by SDC. SDC is constantly reviewing and renewing its attractions on Sentosa. For example, Siloso Beach has become a major attraction now. The Musical Foundation, which changes its shows regularly to attract visitors, and the Images of Singapore are also popular with tourists.

    As for the private attractions on Sentosa, they have their own product life cycle. SDC is encouraging them to renew the attractions and put in new investments by offering incentives. If they apply, SDC will consider them favourably.

    Apart from providing incentives, SDC is also implementing various measures to attract visitors to Sentosa. For example, the Mega Savers Scheme is quite successful. As stated by the Minister yesterday, we are going to do a strategic review of Sentosa to reposition it as a world class tourist attraction.

    Mr Inderjit Singh also commented on the performance of our tourism sector. Last year, there was a decline in tourist arrivals by 12%. Because of this, STB has stepped up their promotion efforts. There is a $30 million marketing campaign called "Once in a Millennium Offer". This will run from June this year to August next year and there will be a series of activities and events to attract visitors to Singapore.

Column: 589



    As far as visa procedures are concerned, STB is working closely with the Ministry of Home Affairs. In fact, leisure groups from China can now apply for double-entry visas. As for group tourists from China, it is easier now for them to apply for visas. For tourists from India, Myanmar and Blangadesh, they can now apply for a 2-year or 5-year multiple journey visas if they are businessmen or staff of the tourism-related companies.

    STB is also considering the possibility of developing sports tourism. STB is trying to anchor strategic world-class sporting events in Singapore. It will explore financial and fiscal incentives to achieve this.

    I agree with Mr Rai that we should capitalise on our multi-cultural richness. One example is the Chinatown project. We will do more in this area so that we can attract tourists to stay in Singapore a little longer.

    For companies in the tourism industry which want to upgrade and improve their services, they can, in fact, apply for incentives under the Tourism Development Assistance Scheme. This year STB has projected that tourist arrivals to Singapore will increase by 1% to 3%. We have to put in more efforts in order to achieve this.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok and Dr Toh See Kiat brought up cases involving trading of soft commodities.

    Sir, currently only rubber and coffee futures are gazetted under the Commodity Futures Act (CFA). My Ministry is considering whether extending the CFA to cover futures trading in other commodities will help to deal with the "bucket-shop" problem. We are also examining the regulatory regimes of other countries such as the US and UK to see if they work and are appropriate for us. We will be discussing with the relevant Ministries and agencies on possible approaches to deal with this problem.

    I must say this is a very complicated subject. An important principle is that we should not over-regulate. When we

Column: 590

regulate, the regulations must be effective.

    No regulatory system can protect investors from fraud if they make foolish decisions or enter into one-sided contracts without due diligence. They should be discerning when responding to advertising claims and stay away from dubious investment schemes that promise unrealistically high returns. They must be more vigilant when contemplating unfamiliar and risky new investments.

    Sir, Dr Toh See Kiat also raised the issue of retail price maintenance. My Ministry replied to a similar question some time ago and the position remains unchanged. The best way to prevent price fixing behaviour is to promote competition in the market place, and to maintain a free and open economy so that there are no barriers to the flow of goods in and out of Singapore. This allows retailers, producers and consumers to buy from all sources at the most competitive prices, even from abroad. Retailers who face pressure from their usual suppliers to sell their goods at set prices can, and should, source for alternative suppliers.

    My Ministry administers the Price Control Act. If necessary, we can use this Act to deal with the problem. Meanwhile, we are monitoring the situation closely. We are also studying the experiences of other countries in this respect.

    Dr Lily Neo is concerned over the presence of toxic chemicals in toys. There were also reports in the newspapers expressing similar concerns. In view of this, the Ministry of the Environment recently has made analysis on some samples of Teletubby toys and infant feeding devices and found the results to be satisfactory. There were no phthalates detected. The Ministry of the Environment said that they would continue to make checks whenever they receive reports of toxic substances in toys.

    I would like to assure Members that we are monitoring this closely. Should there be an assessment that there are substances in toys or other products that

Column: 591

render them unsafe for the public, the Government would take necessary actions. It is not necessary to set up another regulatory body just for this purpose.

    Mr Ong Kian Min has commented on our efforts to attract world class exhibitions and conferences to Singapore. We have managed to achieve quite a lot in this area. For example, mega exhibitions like Asian Aerospace, Food and Hotel Asia and Communic Asia have come to Singapore.

    In terms of infrastructure and exhibition space, we have enough to cater to our needs. With the completion of the Singapore Expo which provides 60,000 sq metres of space, we are able to accommodate world-class events. If there is a need, we can add another 40,000 sq metres to a site nearer to the Singapore Expo.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen has urged the Government to use more recycled water and sea water. We are doing this. For example, we work closely with industries and encourage them to use recycled water. Industries like electronics and electroplating use recycled water. For example, wafer fabrication plants recycle their water up to 50% per day, which is equivalent to the size of 11 swimming pools.

    As for sea water, I can inform the Member that those industries located near the seafront such as power stations and refineries are using sea water. In fact, the volume of sea water they use everyday can fill five MacRitchie reservoirs. So we have achieved a lot in this area and we are trying to encourage industries to use more sea water.

    Mr Simon Tay and Mr Chuang Shaw Peng touched on the subject of energy efficiency. I must inform the House that the Government has implemented various incentive schemes to encourage our companies and industries to use energy more efficiently. On the part of PUB, it

Column: 592

conducts regular energy audits and it also organises seminars and workshops so that the latest information can be disseminated to the industries and companies. Singapore Power, in fact, is also very keen to promote energy efficiency. For example, it receives students from schools to their power plants so that they know how important it is to use energy efficiently.

    The Chairman: Mr Lim, would you like to withdraw your amendment?

    Mr Lim Swee Say: Sir, I thank both the Minister and the Senior Parliamentary Secretary for their very comprehensive replies. I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head W of the Main Estimates be reduced by $10 in respect of Code WB 1500.

    Sir, I understand that the Department of Statistics has used administrative data from various Government agencies to set up a household registration database. A national database on dwellings has also been set up. With this detailed data available to the Government, it would be very convenient for the Government to know the details of individual households or even individual citizens just by a few strokes on the keyboard.

    I would like to know whether the Government has plans to expand the database further by including also, for instance, income expenditure and other personal information available from Government agencies, such as the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore, CID, MINDEF, Immigration, LTA, CPF, Elections Department or even the commercial banks.

    Sir, in the electronic world today, and especially in Singapore, where the Government advocates the use of electronic transactions in almost every aspect of payment and transaction, every

Column: 593

citizen is fast losing his privacy without even realising it. Instead of having a more transparent Government, what we will have in Singapore will be a transparent population with every citizen like a sotong in the sea. Singaporeans must be aware of what all these databases mean for them.

    The Chairman: Mr Low, are you expecting a reply? Or you want to continue?

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: What I would like to know from the Government is how would the Government protect the privacy of individual citizens in view of the databases available now?

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Lee Yock Suan): I can assure Members that the data collected under the household registration database are strictly confidential and they are prohibited from release to anybody other than for official statistical purposes.

    As to the actual details of the data, I cannot give him the information now. But I take his point that it is important that the data should not be wrongly made use of. Basically, it is to facilitate our planning purposes to know what is happening to the population. For example, there is no way that we can find out from this data how people have voted in the elections.

    Under the Statistics Act, no particulars or information pertaining to any individual person shall be disclosed to any other person or agency. Only aggregated statistics can be compiled and released for statistical and analytical purposes.

    Head Q -

    The Chairman: Head Q - Ministry of Home Affairs. Amendment No. (1), Mr Chng Hee Kok.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok (East Coast): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head Q of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, the recent report of the rise in crime by 5.2% to 48,260 cases in 1998 is cause for concern. Another worrying trend is that juvenile crime is also on the rise. Although the Commissioner for Police has taken pains to explain that the rise in crime is no cause for alarm, rising crime is always a cause for concern.

    Rising crime statistics, especially when Singapore is perceived to be relatively crime free, always unsettle people. Our crime free and disciplined society is very often touted as a very strong plus point for foreign investors and visitors. It is not likely that we shall lose this overnight, but over an extended period, if the trend continues, we may just lose this competitive edge. We just cannot afford to lose this plus factor, especially one that I feel is within our control.

    Several reasons were advanced for the increase in crime rates ranging from the economic slowdown to the presence of foreign workers and illegal immigrants. The increase in crime coincided with the advent of the economic crisis. It appears to be a given that during tough economic conditions, more resort to crime. I wonder if this is true of disciplined societies like South Korea. Will an ordinarily law abiding citizen resort to crime when that person loses a job? If these offenders resort to crime because they cannot make ends meet and not because they are greedy or bad per se, this is indeed a sign of desperate times. Perhaps we must do

Column: 595

more to help these people cope with their hardships, which is a perfectly good crime preventive measure. With retrenchments on the rise this year, it must mean that our crime rate will worsen. Something has to be done to arrest the situation. Perhaps the Minister will like to highlight to the House how the Home Team is planning to cope with the worsening situation.

    Sir, besides the reasons advanced for the declining crime situation, a rise in crime rate may indicate that insufficient focus was placed on policing activities due to declining manpower or manpower cuts. As part of our restructuring in making our police officers more effective and justifying reducing our manpower needs, one must wonder if the setting up of the NPCs has resulted in the lower presence of our neighbourhood policemen. It could be due to the change in policing that has given criminals a wrong signal and encouraged them to try their luck now that less policemen are patrolling by foot or on bicycles. It is an undeniable fact that the presence of the police does deter crime just as the presence of a traffic police officer would deter speeding. I raised this concern two years ago on the structural changes in our policing methods and a drop in police presence. Could the Minister please enlighten us on whether the crime rates in areas that previously have neighbourhood police posts have increased after the NPPs were closed, and is there any drop in the number of crime reports in areas after the NPCs were set up?

    Sir, I am also worried by the apparent increase in crimes being committed by teenagers and youths, especially those that resulted in injury during robbery attempts. We have just been confronted by the most recent case of murder allegedly committed by three young children. Our young criminals appear to be much younger, more fearless and increasingly more violent. What could possibly have happened that have caused them to be beyond parental control? Will the Minister highlight to this House the efficacy of his Ministry's efforts in working

Column: 596

with other Ministries on crime prevention work amongst students and the youths that have dropped out of schools?

    Currently, youth offenders under 16 cannot be named to protect their identity. With widespread public education and access to media anti-crime messages, I am not sure if this should be changed.     This is why we have always insisted on the Government's right of reply for newspapers and broadcasters which target Singaporeans. We have to flow with the tide in order to retain some freedom for ourselves. We have to maintain a certain degree of autonomy and find our own separate identity in the world, which we must if we are to remain competitive and be of service to others. Some people think that IT will eventually make all of us Americans one day. I doubt it. Yes, others also face the same challenge, like the French, the Germans, the Japanese and the Chinese. But they are determined they will be themselves and retain their own separate identities and I think we should do so too. But we can

only do so by skilfully moving with the technology, not by being reactionary. And those Asian countries which cling to old positions rigidly will be undermined and will be swept aside. But we have got to play this game in a smarter way.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan today and Mr Low Thia Khiang and many others during the MND debate asked many questions about SCV and why is it HDB flat owners are cabled up for free while others have to pay some money. Dr Lee Tsao Yuan asked why it was SCV and not the Government who laid our cable network. She asked what aspects of SCV SBA regulates and how much subsidies are involved in laying the cable network. Because of the great interest shown in this House at this Budget debate on SCV, I would like to make a detailed clarification of the issues raised.

    In 1995, the Government agreed to let SCV lay an advanced island-wide cable network by 1st January 2000, in return for a limited 7-year monopoly on cable TV which will end in June 2002. This network is an important national infrastructure that could be used not only for cable TV but also for interactive multimedia services. Because of technological and market risks, the Government decided that Singapore's interests are best served by having the project commercially driven. Because we will not know how the technologies will change, how the policies will change, what new trends and new products will come to be, it was better from the start to make it a commercial undertaking than to develop it as a national infrastructure project.

    The alternative of managing it as public infrastructure would have made it much less responsive to technological and market changes. So, a private company was chosen to lay the infrastructure and provide services on a commercial basis. The shareholders are SIM, SPH, Singapore Technologies and Media One International, which is the third largest cable operator in the US.

    SBA regulates SCV on its cable roll-out plan, programming standards, customer service and inter-connection issues but not the details of SCV subscription rates and cabling charges, which are quite complex. While SCV has been given exclusive franchise in the provision of subscription TV, this exclusivity is limited both in scope and in duration. Let me explain. As a TV distributor, SCV faces strong competition from the terrestrial channels provided by the SIM group of companies. SBA requires it to carry most of the terrestrial channels for free, which is an unusual practice in the cable TV business. SBA has also allowed SingTel to offer video on demand and other broadband services like Magix. SCV's monopoly position is therefore a limited one. SCV's exclusive franchise is for 7 years, in exchange for which it is required to wire up the entire island, regardless of take-up by Singaporeans. In some countries, such as in the US, cable operators may be given up to 15 years exclusive franchise for cabling up households above the ground. SCV is required to lay all cables underground which makes the undertaking much more costly.

    SCV is aware from the very outset that its financial outlay will be considerable while its monopoly position is short. It knows that when its franchise ends in June 2002, the Government will be allowing other subscription TV services, both wired and wireless, including satellite, to operate here. SCV therefore cannot be complacent and its strategy is therefore to attract subscribers for the long term. Only if there are many long-term subscribers can SCV hope to recover its investment and make a decent return on shareholders' capital. SCV must therefore charge cable TV in a way which could win it a large base of loyal long-term customers.

    The cost of cabling varies with the dwelling type. Hence, HDB flats are cheaper to cable up than private highrise which are in turn cheaper than landed properties. For landed properties, again it varies, whether it is a terrace or bungalow.

SCV's cost of cabling up all HDB flats amounted to $242 million. They receive $60 million from HDB, being the amount HDB would have to pay itself had it continued maintaining and upgrading its existing central antenna system in HDB estates. This comes with the flat, and HDB has an obligation to provide and maintain it and upgrade it from time to time when new channels become available. What HDB has done is to pass this buck to SCV and to pay SCV the amount it calculates it has to pay anyway if it undertook the responsibility for itself.

    Neither HDB nor the Government subsidises SCV for cabling the estates. SCV decided that the difference of $182 million was worth incurring because of the advantage the large HDB customer base would give it over future competitors after its monopoly ends.

    Condominium dwellers pay a rate of $150 for the first cable point or $240 for the first two cable points. The cost of external wiring amounting to some $25 million is absorbed fully by SCV.

    For the cabling of landed properties, SCV decided to divide them into two groups. There are some 55,000 units, mostly terraces, semi-detached houses and small bungalows, which are located in or near mixed neighbourhoods, and they are near the main cable tap off points, so that they are easier to wire up. SCV's cost, on average, of cabling each of these homes, regardless of take-up, is about $2,300. This means that if one out of two homes subscribes to SCV, the cost of laying the cable per subscriber is $4,600, compared to the $2,300 which SCV charges per household.

    There is another group of some 5,000 bungalows located in low-density areas further away from the main cable tap off points. The cost of cabling such homes on average is $8,000 per unit, again regardless of the take-up. And if one in two bungalows subscribes, the cost to cable each bungalow subscriber is in fact $16,000, because you have to go a long

Column: 693

way to reach one home. But in order to make it more attractive for these households to subscribe, SCV decided to charge each of these households about $6,000 in 2- or 3-year instalments.

    The cost to SCV of cabling up all landed properties is $177 million. Hence, at a 50% take-up rate, SCV would have to bear some $97 million in cabling costs for landed properties in Singapore. It is therefore completely untrue that landed property owners are subsidising condominium or HDB flat owners. SCV has decided to absorb a higher loss per household for landed properties as it believes that the take-up rate will be higher among such households. And this in fact has been borne out by their experience. According to SCV, the actual subscription rate is about 18% for HDB homes, less for 2- and 3-rooms, more for 4- and 5-rooms and Executive flats; 35% for private high-rise homes and about 40% for landed estates. This is actually an encouraging figure, given that our cable TV service started only in 1995. As a comparison, Hong Kong, which started its cable service in 1993 has a take-up rate of 24%. In the US, it took 50 years to reach a 70% take-up rate.

    It would not have been desirable for SBA to regulate the prices charged by SCV. Too many factors were involved, too many assumptions would have to be made. SBA could at best have set ceiling rates based on infrastructural cost recovery, but as I have explained, SCV's charges are well below infrastructural cost recovery.

    The Government will provide two buildings in Kampong Glam for the Foundation to house the Centre, the Istana Kampong Glam as well as the building next to it, which is known as the Bendahara House.     The development of the Centre should reflect the history of Kampong Glam. Being the seat of Malay royalty, it existed before Raffles arrived. After 1819, the Malay community in Singapore grew rapidly and included Arabs, Indians, Indian Muslims, Javanese, Buginese, Banjaris, Boyanese and others. And indeed the sense of a mixed community with diverse heritage is still evident in Kampong Glam today, names like Arab Street and Bussorah Street. Separate sections in Kampong Glam accommodated different groups like Kampong Melaka, Kampong Java, Kampong Bugis. Till today, some of our best Padang restaurants by Minang people are still to be found there.

    There are also Chinese stone masons and ironmongers, shopkeepers, making Kampong Glam a truly cosmopolitan district with its own distinct character. And nearby is the Sultan Mosque, which was planned for by Raffles, and it is interesting that till today, the trustees of the Mosque must include two North Indians, two South Indians, two Malays, two Javanese, two Buginese and two Arabs. So very early, the community decided that it must ensure wide representation. The Centre that we are establishing should somehow capture that old spirit, and through that old spirit, continue to link the Malay community in Singapore to all four corners of the Archipelago.

Just as many Chinese in Singapore can trace part of their ancestry back to Chinatown, many Malay Muslims in Singapore can trace part of their ancestry back to Kampong Glam. Recently, there was a bit of public commotion over STB's plan to redevelop Chinatown. It created some inconveniences to STB, but it was a very good debate, because it showed that Singaporeans have strong emotional bonds to the land, and are concerned about what for them is sacred ground should be treated. In fact, if Singaporeans had showed no interest to the way Chinatown was being redeveloped, then we should worry, because it would then mean that we are just a hotel for Singaporeans, and Singaporeans are themselves rootless citizens with no sense of where they come from and who they are.
